It's understandable why someone might think that way, but it's also important to remember the historical context of Cicero's actions. At the time, the Republic was undergoing significant changes, and there was a lot of uncertainty and instability. Cicero believed that the things he spoke out against, like the rise of authoritarian leaders and the erosion of the rule of law, were leading the Republic down a dangerous path. 

Moreover, Cicero was a statesman who took his role in the government very seriously. For him, defending the Republic and the principles it stood for was his duty, and he felt a moral obligation to do so. He believed that it was better to risk his own life than to compromise his beliefs and abandon the values that he felt were essential to the survival of the Republic.

Therefore, while one may disagree with Cicero's actions, it's important to recognize that he acted out of a deep commitment to the ideals of the Republic and the principles of good governance.
